record.attribute: CryptoDB is an integrated genomic and functional genomic database for the parasite Cryptosporidium. CryptoDB integrates whole genome sequence and annotation along with experimental data and environmental isolate sequences provided by community researchers . The database includes supplemental bioinformatics analyses and a web interface for data-mining.

• Cryptosporidium parvum
  • Cryptosporidium hominis
  • Cryptosporidium muris
  • environmental isolate sequences from numerous species

• The EuPathDB Data Summary provides an overview of the content in Eu PathDB across sites, all organisms and data types covered.
  • The EuPathDB Gene Metrics Table summarizes the number of genes for the o rganisms currently available in EuPathDB, by various datatypes.

There are several kinds of downloads available in a EuPathDB site:
  • Download files that we create at release time. The link to access these files is under the menu item "Downloads":"Data Files". These include fasta files for all available sequences, gff files with complete gene information, and other formats.
  • Download files with results generated by running searches. From a result page (after running a search) a user can access the "Download Results" link, to a new page where a few different download formats are offered. The file for download includes all IDs in the result. The user selects a format and, in some formats, the user may request additional information about each ID in the result: single valued attributes (e.g., exon count for a geneID) and multi-valued tables (e.g., set of EC numbers for a geneID).
  • Download files that have been uploaded by the community in our websites, available under "Downloads" or "Community".
  • Download EuPathDB publications, under the menu item "Downloads".

Each project in EuPathDB benefits from the advice and mentoring of people from each specific community.

CryptoDB

  • Lihua Xiao (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, USA)

CryptoDB is a member of pathogen-databases that are housed under the NIAID-funded EuPathDB Bioinformatics Resource Center (BRC) umbrella. The EuPathDB team is mainly distributed between the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania and the University of Georgia in Athens, Georgia.

The data at this site is provided freely for public use, through the contributions of many researchers including those involved in generating the genome sequences. The data is not guaranteed to be accurate as it often reflects the results of ongoing research. When using data obtained from any EuPathDB project, it is important to cite the original publications and contributors of that data.
Please see Citing CryptoDB below.

When citing CryptoDB itself, please use:

CryptoDB: a Cryptosporidium bioinformatics resource update. 2006 Jan 1;34:D419-22. Heiges M, et al.

Much of the data in CryptoDB is provided by independent researchers. Please cite them if you use their data. For a list of the data integrated into CryptoDB and the related publications please see Data Sources.
